audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker greeting the audience. He introduces himself and his role at a location named "Ayuka", mentioning they are celebrating the "seven-year completion of Associate Mission." He explains that Associate is India's first multi-wavelength astronomy satellite launched in September 2015 by the Indian Space Research Organization. He sounds happy about the seven years, elaborating on Ayuka's contributions to the Associate mission, including instrumentation, calibration, operation, user support, and science.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Professor Shyam Tandon, mentioning his role in a major instrument, the "ultraviolet imaging telescope" on board "Astrosat." He highlights the professor's leading role in its development and the "fantastic images of the sky" it produced in the ultraviolet band. He continues to describe how Ayuca scientists have used the instrument to produce "some of the best results." The speaker maintains an informative, slightly excited tone throughout.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing Professor Deepankar Bhattacharya, who has recently moved to Ashoka University. He says the professor is the payload manager and principal investigator of the Cadmium Zinc Telluride Imager payload, and that he has contributed in all aspects of the instrument. The speaker then notes that they run the Payload Operation Center for the instrument, where they receive raw data from ISRO, process it, and send it back to ISRO, which distributes the data to scientists around the country and outside India.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, in an informative and slightly enthusiastic tone, discussing the development of the Astrosat proposal system, designed to assist scientists in India and elsewhere with preparing and submitting proposals for observations. He explains that this software system aids in the operation of the mission based on the scientific proposals. The speaker then mentions the Astrosat Science Support Cell, which hosts relevant information useful for using Astrosat data and producing scientific results. Furthermore, the speaker describes conducting training workshops for students and seniors to use Astrosat data.

A man speaks about his instrument, which is a camera that will see in the ultraviolet wavelength. He describes developing the controllers, data acquisition system and detector controller in the lab and how they were later modified and used in space. He mentions they worked on the UAIT part of Astrosat, which uses a star 250 imager sensor. He explains the detectors they purchased were not space qualified, so they bought off-the-shelf devices that were space qualified with help from TIF and ISRO.  He details the design and development of the data equation system and high-speed detector controller in the instrumentation lab, having started the project in 2003 and worked on it for two to three years. Afterwards, in the years 2010-2012 work continued in smaller pieces to resolve issues or update old documentation.

The audio features a male speaker describing his work on black hole X-ray binary systems, noting the presence of a black hole and companion star orbiting a center of mass. He mentions gaseous exchange leading to the formation of an accretion disk emitting high energy X-rays. The tone is informative and professional.

The clip begins with a quiet, non-descript "oh." Then, a male speaker begins discussing features "related to the x-rays," mentioning that the variability "is aperiodic in nature," and happens "on multiple time scales." He says his group is looking for "the cause of this variability."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that they're using data from India's multi-wavelength observatory, AstroSat, and its five payloads. He notes they're using the data from two payloads, highlighting "Lax PC" as a proportional counter and emphasizing its "good timing resolution" and coverage of the "hard X-ray range." He then mentions using "SX-T," an imaging telescope that covers the "soft X-ray range," concluding that the "conjunction of the two" is good for their studies.

The audio begins with a single female speaker expressing happiness about the completion of a project's 7-year milestone, exceeding its initial timeframe. She mentions looking forward to publications and data use from an observatory. Her research interest revolves around accretion disc study of compact objects and black hole x-ray binary sources, using data from specific instruments on board. The speaker maintains a positive and informative tone throughout.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing his primary field of research, involving the evolution of galaxies and how they assemble mass over time. He mentions studying star-forming dwarf galaxies observed by an Indian satellite, AstroSat, expressing hope that the work will further understanding of dwarf galaxy evolution and galaxy formation as a whole. The speech is calm and informational. In the background, a sound like water flowing or a stream runs steadily.

A male speaker with a formal tone discusses the advantages of being at Ayuka, mentioning it's an inter-university center and receives visitors, including students, researchers, and faculty, who use the resources available at the associate science support cell, resulting in excellent results. He says that Associate has become an international space observatory where people from India use data and submit proposals. He continues, reporting that Associate has produced over 300 research papers, hoping it will continue to operate.
The audio clip features one speaker, a male, expressing gratitude with a simple "Thank you very much."
